channel.title: Metals Industry News Feed
channel.description: Automated news feed for aluminum, steel, copper, and nickel industries

item.title: Cavi in rame, Antitrust avvia indagine su presunto cartello: Prysmian e Nexans in calo in Borsa
item.description: L’Autorità Antitrust italiana (AGCM) ha avviato un’indagine su un presunto cartello tra alcuni dei principali produttori di cavi in rame a bassa tensione in Italia, tra cui Prysmian Cavi e Sistemi Italia, ipotizzando un coordinamento sui prezzi a partire dal 2005.[1] Sono state effettuate ispezioni presso le sedi delle società coinvolte e di alcuni distributori; in Borsa il titolo Prysmian ha registrato un calo, anche se vari analisti stimano un impatto economico limitato perché il mercato italiano dei cavi in rame a bassa tensione pesa per meno del 3% sui ricavi del gruppo.[1]

item.title: Prysmian shares rise as Italian cable maker seen as winner amid US copper tariffs
item.description: Le azioni Prysmian sono salite fino al 4% sulla Borsa di Milano dopo l’annuncio di nuovi dazi statunitensi sull’import di rame, con il gruppo visto dagli analisti come uno dei principali beneficiari grazie alla sua integrazione verticale e fornitura domestica di rame negli USA.[2] Gli esperti ritengono che Prysmian, grande acquirente globale di rame con un’importante presenza nel mercato americano, possa trasferire i maggiori costi ai clienti e rafforzare i margini nel business dei cavi a bassa tensione negli Stati Uniti.[2]

item.title: Period of elevated copper prices overextended: analysts
item.description: S&P Global reports that LME copper has repeatedly set new records, climbing from around $11,000/mt in late October to over $13,200/mt in early January, levels many analysts see as exceeding fundamentals.[5] While StoneX still expects high average prices near $11,490/mt in 2026, analysts highlight weakening downstream demand in China and diverging views between bullish Western funds and more bearish Chinese traders.[5]

item.title: Period of elevated copper prices overextended: analysts
item.description: Analysts warn that copper prices have exceeded sustainable levels due to supply disruptions and speculation. StoneX forecasts 2026 copper prices averaging $11,490/mt, while Chinese traders hold bearish positions contrasting with Western bullish sentiment.

item.title: Alcoa Slips 4% As JPMorgan Turns Bearish on the Aluminum Stock
item.description: Alcoa shares fell about 4% after JPMorgan downgraded the stock to **“underweight”**, arguing that its valuation has run ahead of fundamentals despite aluminum prices recently exceeding **$3,000 per metric ton**, their highest since spring 2022.[1] The bank expects aluminum market surpluses later in 2026 as roughly 1.5 million tons of new Indonesian supply comes online, which could put downward pressure on prices even as U.S. and Canadian market premiums remain elevated but vulnerable to tariff policy changes.[1]

item.title: Copper prices hit yet another record on supply and tariff fears
item.description: Benchmark three-month copper on the London Metal Exchange rose 1.8% to $13,225 a tonne, with the metal gaining about 6.6% so far in 2026. Supply disruptions from strikes at major mines and US trade uncertainty continue to fuel the sharp early-year rally across base metals.

item.title: Aluminum Raw Material Price Trends in January 2026
item.description: JASTOO reports that aluminum raw material prices are rising steadily in early 2026, supported by strong global demand and **advancements in sustainable production technologies**.[4] The trend is encouraging investment in R&D for lighter, more energy‑efficient wheel components, aligning with broader automotive sustainability goals.[4]

item.title: Clean energy supply chains of the future need a circular economy
item.description: The article discusses how circular economy approaches can strengthen critical mineral supply chains for the clean energy transition following COP30. It highlights that recycled nickel, cobalt, and lithium produce approximately 80% fewer greenhouse gas emissions than primary mining, creating competitive advantages for low-carbon supply chains.

item.title: Nickel Market Volume Expected at 4.4 Mn Tons by 2031 on Strong Stainless Steel and EV Demand
item.description: Market analysis projects nickel demand will reach 4.4 million tons by 2031, driven by stainless steel and electric vehicle battery production. North America is developing domestic nickel supply projects aligned with clean energy and EV manufacturing needs.

item.title: National Aluminium Share Price Today, January 8
item.description: National Aluminium Co Ltd shares were trading down about 3.9% in early trade on January 8 after a strong run to fresh record highs in recent sessions, which had been underpinned by rising global aluminum prices and positive industry fundamentals.[5] The stock remains significantly higher over the past year, reflecting improved profitability and sentiment tied to the global aluminum price uptrend.[5]

item.title: Commodity Radar: Bauxite helps to hold the capesize market
item.description: China is keeping its primary aluminium production capped at 45 million tonnes per year, with output for the first 11 months of 2025 reported at 41.4 million tonnes, implying limited December production capacity to stay within the cap.[5] The article notes that this cap supports continued strong bauxite and alumina demand, and that growing aluminium smelting capacity in countries such as Indonesia could drive higher alumina exports from China and alter future bauxite trade flows.[5]

item.title: CES 2026: Reviewed announces its awards for tech's best products
item.description: Features innovative aluminum alloy technology in consumer products, including a trademarked aluminum alloy that is significantly stronger than standard 6061 aluminum and outperforms TA2 titanium in key strength metrics. The material engineering provides exceptional resistance to dents, scratches, and long-term wear without adding bulk.

item.title: Steel falls as China growth worries cap recent gains
item.description: Benchmark Chinese steel prices slipped to about 3,146 CNY/ton, down around 0.4% from the previous day, even though they remain roughly 3% higher over the past month.[1] The market has been supported by expectations of fresh Chinese policy easing, but lingering concerns about construction demand and the broader economy are limiting further upside.[1]

item.title: Tata Steel India posts best-ever quarterly crude steel output in Q3FY26
item.description: In its Q3 update, Tata Steel India reported its **best-ever quarterly crude steel production** at 6.34 million tonnes, up about 12% quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year, driven by higher output at its Jamshedpur and Kalinganagar plants.[1] The update also notes that Tata Steel Netherlands produced 1.68 million tonnes of liquid steel with deliveries of 1.40 million tonnes in Q3FY26.[1]

item.title: Budget 2027: Assocham seeks incentives for hydrogen-based green steel production
item.description: Industry body Assocham has urged the Indian government to offer incentives for **hydrogen-based direct reduced iron (DRI)** and concessional green finance to support the steel sector’s transition to low-carbon production in the FY27 Budget.[3] The group highlights that despite India’s 8–9% steel growth and position as the world’s second-largest producer, high input costs, dependence on imported coking coal, stagnant iron ore production, and pressure on raw material supply are constraining capacity and raising costs.[3]

item.title: Union Budget: Assocham seeks incentives for hydrogen steel, green finance
item.description: Ahead of India’s Union Budget, Assocham has called for policy support including incentives for **hydrogen-based steelmaking**, concessional green finance, and stronger backing for recycling and R&D to help expand low-carbon steel capacity.[6] The chamber warns that elevated raw material costs, a weak rupee, and near-total reliance on imported coking coal are squeezing margins and could hinder future capacity additions without supportive measures.[6]

item.title: Gov't discusses response to EU's carbon tax policy with steel industry
item.description: South Korea’s Ministry of Trade, Industry and Resources met with major domestic steelmakers to discuss responses to the EU’s **Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM)**, which began applying to carbon-intensive imports such as steel on January 1.[4] Steel producers said they have prepared compliance measures, including securing EU-recognized carbon verification, but requested continued government efforts to reduce uncertainties around the evolving policy, which could affect export competitiveness and future investment decisions.[4]

item.title: Europe's steel industry faces its 2026 reckoning with CBAM
item.description: From January 2026, the EU’s **Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism** begins to materially impact Europe’s steelmakers, marking a turning point where climate policy starts to reshape steel sector balance sheets.[5] The article explains how CBAM aims to protect EU producers from carbon leakage by imposing a carbon cost on imported steel, which could influence capacity utilization, investment in low-carbon technologies, and the competitive landscape between domestic and foreign producers.[5]

item.title: The price of copper is expected to reach a historic high of $13,000 per tonne in 2026
item.description: The article discusses expectations that copper prices could climb to about $13,000 per tonne in 2026, driven largely by structural supply constraints and accelerating demand from energy transition technologies.[4] It reviews current mine output, projected production growth, and the risk that new capacity additions will not be sufficient to close the anticipated supply gap in refined copper.[4]

item.title: A Canary in an Urban Mine: Environmental and Economic Impacts of Urban Mining
item.description: CSIS analyzes how ‘urban mining’—recovering metals such as copper and gold from e‑waste—can be as cost‑efficient as traditional mining in China while offering a smaller environmental footprint.[4] The piece discusses how scaling recycling and urban mining could ease supply constraints for critical materials used in clean energy and high‑tech applications, reduce dependence on primary mining, and support more sustainable industrial systems.[4]

item.title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel Prices Retreat from Highs on January 8 as Market Sentiment Shifts from Frenzy to Caution
item.description: Nickel prices on the SHFE pulled back after a sharp rally, with the most-traded 2602 contract closing down about 2.3% around 142,020 yuan/mt, as sentiment turned from aggressive buying to more cautious profit‑taking.[1] Spot #1 refined nickel averaged 149,050 yuan/mt, down 1,100 yuan/mt day‑on‑day, while a sharp one‑day increase of 20,000 mt in LME inventories to 270,000 mt raised concerns about oversupply and near‑term volatility.[1]

item.title: Nickel prices surge on Indonesian curbs, but policy U-turn risk looms
item.description: Indonesia’s decision to cut nickel mining quotas has sharply boosted global nickel prices, underscoring the country’s dominant role in supply.[5] However, the report notes that pressure is building for a potential policy reversal, which could eventually increase mining permits and production capacity, easing the current tightness in the market.[3][5]

item.title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel prices retreat from highs on January 8 as market sentiment shifts from frenzy to caution
item.description: Nickel prices on the SHFE pulled back on January 8 after a strong rally, with spot refined nickel in China quoted at 143,400–154,700 yuan/mt and average prices down 1,100 yuan/mt from the previous trading day.[1] The review highlights a sharp one‑day increase of 20,000 mt in LME nickel inventories to 270,000 mt and notes that traders are closely watching Indonesia’s nickel policy and future production capacity as key drivers of volatility.[1]

item.title: The first Energy Release contract in the Aosta Valley is underway: agreement signed between the CVA Group and Cogne Acciai Speciali
item.description: CVA will construct four new photovoltaic plants in Sicily with a total capacity of over 20 MW, expected to produce 593,600 MWh annually and be fully operational by 2026. This marks the first Energy Release agreement in the Aosta Valley and supports Cogne Acciai Speciali's green energy transition and reduced environmental impact of production.

item.title: LME aluminium cash offer slips to USD 3,081 as opening stocks fall 4.6% on January 8
item.description: London Metal Exchange aluminium prices eased on January 8, with the cash offer declining to about $3,081 per tonne, down roughly 0.36% from the prior session.[1] The 3‑month contract also weakened, while exchange stocks fell and warrant positioning shifted, indicating tight but volatile market conditions.[1]

item.title: Aluminum Futures Hover Near 3-Year High on Tight Supply
item.description: Aluminum futures in the UK traded around $3,090 per tonne on January 8, staying close to a more than three‑year high amid mounting signs of tighter supply.[2] Prices are up over 8% in the past month and more than 21% year‑on‑year as China keeps a firm cap on output and global demand remains resilient.[2]

item.title: CES Innovation Awards 2026 Honoree: Portable SSD T7 Resurrected
item.description: Samsung’s Portable SSD T7 Resurrected earned a CES 2026 Innovation Award for its circular-design concept built around a 100% recycled aluminum enclosure.[6] The device extends Samsung’s use of aluminum scrap from smartphone production and pairs it with recycled paper packaging, serving as a flagship example of the company’s broader circular-materials and sustainability strategy.[6]

item.title: Poland reduced steel production by 25% y/y in November
item.description: Poland’s steel production fell by about a quarter year‑on‑year in November, reflecting continued weakness in European steel demand and pressure from cheaper imports.[3] The decline highlights broader underutilization of capacity across the EU as mills cut output in response to low margins and subdued construction and manufacturing activity.[3]

item.title: Austria increased steel production by 7.6% y/y in November
item.description: Austria posted a 7.6% year‑on‑year rise in steel production in November, contrasting with declines in several other European countries.[3] The increase suggests better capacity utilization at Austrian mills, likely supported by stronger export orders or domestic industrial demand.[3]

item.title: Spain increased steel production by 5.4% y/y in 1H 2025
item.description: Spanish steelmakers boosted output by 5.4% in the first half of 2025 compared with the same period a year earlier.[3] The growth indicates improved use of installed capacity, supported by recovering construction and infrastructure activity in Spain.[3]

item.title: Global steel production fell by 5.8% y/y in June
item.description: World crude steel production declined 5.8% year‑on‑year in June, signaling a broad-based reduction in output across major producing regions.[3] The drop reflects persistent challenges from weak demand, high input costs, and environmental policy pressures on capacity utilization.[3]

item.title: ArcelorMittal temporarily shuts down blast furnace in Poland due to import pressure
item.description: ArcelorMittal has temporarily idled a blast furnace in Poland in response to intense pressure from low‑priced steel imports.[3] The shutdown reduces local production capacity and underscores competitiveness issues facing EU integrated mills amid rising imports and sluggish domestic demand.[3]

item.title: France reduced steel production by 18.1% year-on-year in June
item.description: French steel production fell 18.1% year‑on‑year in June, one of the steeper declines among major EU producers.[3] The cutback points to significantly underused capacity as French mills respond to weak industrial output and competition from imported steel.[3]

item.title: World crude steel production for 70 countries down 4.6% in November 2025
item.description: Crude steel production across 70 reporting countries reached 140.1 million tonnes in November 2025, down 4.6% compared with November 2024.[5] The contraction highlights reduced operating rates and capacity utilization in multiple regions amid softer global demand and tighter environmental regulations.[5]

item.title: Steel imports up 11.0% in October vs. September
item.description: U.S. steel imports in October rose 11% compared with September, indicating increased reliance on foreign supply even as domestic producers operate below full capacity.[6] Higher imports may further pressure U.S. mill utilization rates, particularly in flat‑rolled products exposed to price‑sensitive buyers.[6]

item.title: El-Marakby Steel launches a new plant to localize production inputs
item.description: El‑Marakby Steel plans to invest about EGP 1 billion (around USD 21 million) in a new plant aimed at localizing production inputs and expanding its product portfolio.[4] The project will add capacity in Egypt’s steel value chain, reducing dependence on imported semifinished materials and enhancing supply security.[4]

item.title: Turbulence ahead: how current and future trade measures affect steel and aluminum capacity decisions
item.description: Clyde & Co analyzes how U.S. tariffs of around 50% on most steel and aluminum imports are reshaping global capacity decisions and encouraging more localized production.[7] The report notes that persistent Section 232 tariffs and retaliatory measures are prompting foreign producers to consider new steel and aluminum facilities inside the U.S. to bypass trade barriers.[7]

item.title: Copper prices near all-time high: Structural shift or speculative spike? Here’s where the red metal is headed
item.description: The article reports that copper prices are trading near record levels, driven by a mix of tightening global supply, strong structural demand from electrification, and speculative flows.[1][3] It examines whether the current rally signals a long-term structural bull market or a short‑term speculative spike, and outlines key risks such as Chinese demand softness and potential policy shocks.[1][5]

item.title: Goldman Sachs raises first-half copper price forecast
item.description: Goldman Sachs has lifted its copper price forecast for the first half of 2026 to $12,750/mt from $11,525/mt, reflecting the stronger‑than‑expected rally and persistent tightness in supply.[7] The bank cites robust demand from electrification and infrastructure alongside constrained mine output, while still anticipating some moderation from peak spot levels above $13,000/mt.[2][7]

item.title: Copper futures retreat slightly from record highs
item.description: Trading Economics notes that copper futures recently pulled back to around $5.79–$5.8 per pound after hitting all‑time highs above $6 per pound, as some investors took profits.[3][4] Despite the minor correction, prices remain up more than 35% year‑on‑year, supported by expectations of Chinese monetary easing and ongoing concerns over global supply.[3]

item.title: ‘Substantial Shortfall’ in Copper Supply Widens as the Race for AI and Growing Defense Spending Add to Accelerating Demand, New S&P Global Study Finds
item.description: S&P Global releases a new study warning that accelerating demand for copper from electrification, AI data centers, renewable energy, EVs, and defense risks turning copper from an enabler of innovation into a bottleneck for growth.[2] The report stresses that closing the looming supply gap will require major investment, new mines, expanded recycling, and policy and permitting reforms to support a more resilient and sustainable copper value chain.[2][1]

item.title: The AI and Defense Boom Threatens to Exacerbate Global Copper Shortage, Warns S&P
item.description: An S&P-linked news item highlights that booming investment in AI and defense is intensifying pressure on already tight global copper supply.[6] It echoes findings that without accelerated mine development and innovation across the copper supply chain, copper shortages could hinder electrification and technology deployment critical to climate and security goals.[6][1]

item.title: Global Nickel Market Recalibrates After Explosive Trading Week
item.description: INN notes that three‑month LME nickel prices stabilized near US$17,900/t on Thursday, January 8, after a week of extreme volatility in which prices surged more than 10% before retreating.[3] The article attributes the swings to heavy Chinese buying, uncertainty over Indonesia’s mining quota approvals, and sharply higher LME inventories (up over 300% since early 2025), suggesting the market is now recalibrating and that future moves will hinge on policy enforcement rather than demand.[3]

item.title: Copper and Nickel Fall on Profit-Taking
item.description: According to a market report carried by Hellenic Shipping News, LME nickel fell 3.8% to about US$17,205/t as traders took profits after the recent sharp rally and as Indonesia held back from disclosing its 2026 mining output quota.[7] The lack of clarity on Indonesian supply, following earlier price spikes driven by expectations of tighter output, prompted a pullback across base metals, with both copper and nickel easing from recent highs.[7]

item.title: Nickel is the leading base metal on the market due to uncertainty about Indonesian output
item.description: The article reports that nickel has become the strongest-performing base metal as traders react to Indonesia’s plan to reduce 2026 nickel mining production quotas, a move designed to support prices. It notes that benchmark LME and Shanghai nickel contracts fell sharply after a recent rally of more than 30%, with analysts warning that oversupply and rising inventories could cap further gains, while policy uncertainty over Indonesian output remains the key driver.[2]

item.title: Global Nickel Market Recalibrates After Explosive Trading Week
item.description: This piece describes how nickel prices stabilized after a highly volatile week marked by double‑digit daily gains and subsequent pullbacks, driven mainly by evolving Indonesian production policies and heavy Chinese buying.[3] It highlights that PT Vale Indonesia temporarily halted mining at its Pomalaa and Bahodopi operations due to delays in 2026 production plan approvals, cutting output to about 30% of normal capacity, while broader uncertainty over final quota levels continues to influence market expectations for supply and capacity.[3]

item.title: Extending product lifecycles: The missing link in circular economy
item.description: This article argues that extending the lifespan of industrial and consumer products is critical to reducing waste, emissions, and resource use in a circular economy. It highlights that sectors like renewable energy and electric vehicles face major supply challenges as demand for critical minerals such as nickel and cobalt is projected to double by 2040, and describes engineering innovations—including advanced coatings, 3D-printed low‑carbon materials, and resilience-based design—that can cut material throughput and improve sustainability.[2]

item.title: Copper Cables: Antitrust Launches Investigation into Alleged Cartel, Prysmian and Nexans Fall on the Stock Exchange
item.description: Italy’s Antitrust Authority (AGCM) has opened an investigation into major low‑voltage copper cable manufacturers for an alleged price‑fixing cartel dating back to 2005, involving companies such as Prysmian Cavi e Sistemi Italia, Nexans’ La Triveneta Cavi, and several other Italian producers.[1] The authority carried out inspections at company headquarters, distributors, and a wholesalers’ federation; analysts currently expect only a negligible impact on Prysmian, as Italian low‑voltage copper cables account for less than 3% of its revenues.[1]

item.title: Tariffs, low stocks push aluminum prices higher in US
item.description: U.S. aluminum consumers are paying **record-high prices**, with costs for some U.S. buyers rising about 40% to above **$5,200 per metric ton** after President Trump doubled import tariffs to 50% in June.[4] Tight global supplies, low U.S. inventories (estimated to have fallen below 300,000 tons from 750,000 tons a year earlier), and a record Midwest premium of 96 cents per pound are amplifying the impact of tariffs and pushing prices well above what transport and levy costs alone would justify.[4]

item.title: Copper Hits $6/LB! Scrap Prices Soar Across the Board to Start 2026
item.description: Copper traded above $6 per pound for the first time in history, driven by supply tightening due to tariffs and slowing imports alongside surging demand from U.S. manufacturing and infrastructure sectors. Analysts forecast continued strength through Q1 2026, with broader scrap market gains across aluminum and catalytic converters.

item.title: The copper boom is just getting started
item.description: Semafor summarizes an S&P Global forecast showing a potential copper supply deficit of 10 million metric tons—about 25% of projected demand—by 2040, driven by electrification, AI data centers, EVs, and defense applications. The article stresses that opening new mines is slow and costly, notes recent disruptions at major operations, and highlights how China’s dozens of smelters and refineries contrast with the United States’ limited processing capacity, pushing countries like Saudi Arabia to rapidly expand refining.[2]

item.title: 'Substantial Shortfall' in Copper Supply Widens as the Race for AI and Growing Defense Spending Add to Accelerating Demand, New S&P Global Study Finds
item.description: S&P Global’s latest study, "Copper in the Age of AI: The Challenges of Electrification," projects that global copper production will peak around 33 million metric tons in 2030 and that, without major new investment, primary mine supply could fall to about 22 million metric tons by 2040. Even with scrap recycling expected to more than double from 4 to 10 million metric tons, the study foresees a 10‑million‑metric‑ton supply deficit—about 25% below projected demand—underscoring the need for new mines and expanded capacity.[1]

item.title: Nickel is the Leading Base Metal on the Market Due to Uncertainty About Indonesian Output
item.description: Nickel outperformed other base metals after the Indonesian government declined to disclose its detailed 2026 mining output quota (RKAB), heightening concerns over a potential rollback of previously signaled supply restrictions.[3] The lack of clarity followed earlier statements about reducing quotas to support prices, leaving the market focused on how strongly Jakarta will ultimately constrain nickel production.[3]

item.title: [CES Innovation Awards® 2026 Honoree] Portable SSD T7 Resurrected
item.description: Samsung’s Portable SSD **T7 Resurrected** received a CES 2026 Innovation Award for its enclosure made from **100% recycled aluminum** and packaging using recycled paper.[5] The design reuses aluminum scrap from smartphone production and serves as a flagship example of Samsung’s circular‑design strategy to reduce environmental impact across product lines.[5]

item.title: Aluminum Silos Market Booms: Food Safety, Sustainability Drive Demand and Innovation in Storage Solutions
item.description: A new market outlook highlights rapid growth in the **aluminum silos** sector, driven by the need for hygienic food storage, sustainability requirements, and design innovation.[9] The report notes that aluminum’s corrosion resistance, recyclability, and lightweight properties are key factors behind its expanding role in modern, efficient storage infrastructure.[9]

item.title: CISA mills' daily crude steel output down 11% in late Dec, stocks also down
item.description: The China Iron and Steel Association (CISA) reported that in late December 2025 (Dec 21–31), average daily crude steel output at large and medium-sized Chinese mills fell to 1.643 million mt, an 11% decline from mid-December levels.[1] Finished steel inventories at these enterprises also decreased sharply, dropping 11.7% between December 20 and December 31, indicating both reduced production and destocking.[1]

item.title: Nickel price surge triggers stainless steel hikes
item.description: LME nickel futures jumped nearly 9% in a single session, closing around $18,524/ton on 6 January amid heavy speculative buying and supply concerns.[6] The sharp increase in nickel costs has prompted stainless steel producers to raise prices, citing higher raw‑material input expenses.[6]

item.title: Greenland grants 30-year permit to EU-backed molybdenum mine
item.description: Greenland Resources has received a 30-year exploitation license for its Malmbjerg molybdenum project, a strategic mine backed by the European Union.[9] The company previously signed offtake agreements with Finland’s Outokumpu and Italy’s Cogne Acciai Speciali, positioning the project as an important future supplier of molybdenum to European stainless steel and specialty steel producers.[9]

item.title: January 9 Aluminum Inventory Update: Significant Drop in Ingots, Slight Increase in Billets
item.description: SMM reports that Chinese aluminum prices have been fluctuating at elevated levels after touching about 23,000 yuan per tonne this week, as inventory data show a notable decline in ingot stocks and a small rise in billet inventories.[5] The combination of high prices and changing stock structure is pressuring billet processing fees and shaping near‑term market dynamics.[5]

item.title: China's aluminium industry cost to fall in January – alumina as key driver
item.description: SMM reports that Chinese aluminium smelters are expected to see **lower production costs in January 2026**, mainly due to a surplus-driven decline in alumina prices and easing auxiliary material costs.[1] Operating alumina capacity may edge down month-on-month, but overall fundamentals remain in surplus, while electricity costs are projected to rebound, slightly offsetting the savings.[1]

item.title: January 9 Aluminum Inventory Update: Significant Drop in Ingots, Slight Increase in Billets
item.description: SMM’s latest daily update shows **social inventory of aluminum ingots in major Chinese consumption regions at about 455,000 tonnes on January 9**, indicating a notable drawdown.[5] Billet inventories, by contrast, recorded a slight increase, suggesting diverging short-term demand patterns between different semi-finished aluminum products.[5]

item.title: HRC Steel Price Edges Lower But Remains Up 33% Year-on-Year
item.description: Hot-rolled coil (HRC) steel prices slipped to about 936–938 USD/ton, down around 0.2% from the previous day but still more than 30% higher than a year earlier.[1] Over the past month, HRC steel has gained roughly 3%, and Trading Economics models project prices could approach 960 USD/ton by the end of the quarter and exceed 1,030 USD/ton over 12 months, signaling expectations of continued firmness in the market.[1]

item.title: ClarkDietrich launches industry-first embodied carbon calculator for steel framing
item.description: ClarkDietrich announced what it calls the steel framing industry’s first embodied carbon calculator, aimed at helping builders and designers quantify and reduce the carbon footprint of cold-formed steel products used in construction.[6] The digital tool is intended to support more sustainable material choices and to align steel framing with emerging low‑carbon building standards and reporting requirements.[6]

item.title: Glencore, Rio Tinto in Merger Discussions
item.description: Glencore and Rio Tinto are in preliminary merger discussions that could create a company valued at over $388 billion. The discussions occur amid surging copper prices exceeding $13,000/tonne, with S&P Global projecting copper demand will reach 42 million tonnes by 2040 while production peaks at 33 million tonnes in 2030.

item.title: Goldman Sachs raises first-half copper price forecast
item.description: Goldman Sachs increased its copper price forecast for the first half of 2026 to $12,750 per metric ton, up from its previous forecast of $11,525 per ton.

item.title: SMM Nickel Midday Review: Nickel Prices Continue to Correct on January 9
item.description: SMM reports that China’s #1 refined nickel price range fell to 135,800–148,000 yuan/mt on January 9, with the average at 141,900 yuan/mt, down 7,150 yuan/mt from the previous trading day, reflecting a sharp pullback after the recent rally.[1] The most-traded SHFE 2602 nickel contract also dropped about 4% intraday, as market sentiment shifted from frenzy to caution amid a stand-off between bullish policy expectations and weak spot demand, with traders closely watching Indonesia’s nickel policy implementation.[1]

item.title: Indonesia to set 2026 coal output quota at around 600 million tons, will adjust nickel quota, minister says
item.description: Covering comments from Indonesia’s energy minister, this report states that the government plans to set the 2026 coal output quota at about 600 million tons and will also adjust nickel production quotas as part of efforts to restore market balance.[5] The minister reiterates that reductions will apply across commodities, including nickel, signaling potential constraints on future nickel output and capacity relative to earlier expectations.[5]

item.title: Aluminum - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
item.description: Aluminum futures rose to about **$3,147.85 per tonne** on January 9, 2026, up 1.9% from the prior day and hovering near a three‑year high, with prices up roughly 9.6% over the past month and more than 22% year over year.[3] The move is driven by tightening supply, including China’s efforts to prevent overcapacity as it nears its 45‑million‑ton output cap, which is limiting production growth and supporting elevated global prices.[3]

item.title: The Catch-Up Rally in Funds Has Ended, and Aluminum Prices Face Short-Term Correction Pressure with Release Imminent
item.description: SMM reports that primary aluminum supply is rising as new smelting projects in China and Indonesia ramp up, with an additional project in Inner Mongolia recently powered on, pointing to further growth in daily output.[1] Downstream demand is weakening ahead of the Chinese New Year as high prices curb consumption and more secondary aluminum and fabrication plants move into holiday shutdowns, setting up near‑term correction pressure despite structurally higher production capacity.[1]

item.title: Hydro and Alumobility collaborate to help automakers meet sustainability targets
item.description: Hydro Extrusions announced a new collaboration with Alumobility, a non‑profit that promotes the use of advanced aluminum solutions in the automotive sector, to help carmakers reduce vehicle weight and lifecycle emissions.[6] The partnership focuses on developing and promoting aluminum-intensive designs and low‑carbon extrusion solutions to support OEMs in meeting tightening sustainability and decarbonization targets.[6]

item.title: InfiMotion Technology showcases leading e‑drive solutions at CES 2026
item.description: InfiMotion Technology unveiled new high‑performance electric drive units at CES 2026 that use ultra‑lightweight magnesium‑aluminum alloy housings to boost power density while cutting weight.[5] The systems are designed to improve EV efficiency and energy economy, illustrating how advanced aluminum alloys support both performance gains and more sustainable electric mobility.[5]

item.title: SMM Hot Rolled & Cold Rolled Production Schedule: Steel Mill Maintenance Completed, January Production Schedule Up MoM
item.description: SMM reports that the **planned January 2026 hot‑rolled coil production** from 39 mainstream Chinese steel mills is about 13.99 million mt, **up 4.6% month‑on‑month** as mills return from maintenance.[1] Planned **cold‑rolled commercial steel** output from 31 mills is 4.10 million mt, up 5.0% from last month, but with demand expected to weaken into late January, inventories may rise and exacerbate supply‑demand imbalances.[1]

item.title: Steel Market Update: Steel Prices and Mill Utilization Heading Into Early 2026
item.description: In this metal market update, Sheffield Metals notes **mill maintenance downtime and restarts**, along with the Nippon/U.S. Steel situation and coating cost increases, as key drivers behind higher steel prices going into Q1 2026.[5] The discussion highlights that as mills come back online and inventories are refilled, **lead times are extending**, indicating tighter short‑term supply even as capacity ramps.[5]

item.title: Steel Prices Edge Higher as China Signals Capacity Limits and Output Falls in November
item.description: Steel prices rose to **3,128 CNY/T on January 9, 2026**, supported by solid margins for Chinese steelmakers, low raw‑material inventories, and a rebound in hot metal production.[4] At the same time, Beijing has **signaled capacity limits on finished steel production** to counter deflation risks, and China’s steel output fell 10.9% year‑on‑year to 70 million tons in November, underscoring a policy‑driven cap on production.[4]

item.title: GalvaNext-2026 highlights Smart, Sustainable Path for Steel Industry
item.description: Coverage of the second day of the GalvaNext‑2026 conference in Jamshedpur details how experts are integrating sustainability into long‑term steel industry planning using smart technologies such as artificial intelligence, IoT and data analytics.[2] Panelists and speakers emphasize innovation in next‑generation galvanizing lines, advanced coatings, and colour‑coating technologies, along with cross‑sector collaboration and workforce upskilling to advance sustainable, future‑ready steel technologies.[2]

item.title: Comex Copper Ends the Week 3.82% Higher at $5.8555 — Data Talk
item.description: Front Month Comex Copper for January delivery gained 21.55 cents per pound, or 3.82% to $5.8555 this week, marking the third highest close in history. The metal is up 41.87% from its 52-week low and off 2.58% from its record high of $6.0105 hit on Tuesday, January 6, 2026.

item.title: Copper Pulls Back From All-Time High
item.description: Copper futures fell to around $5.8 per pound, retreating from record highs as investors took profits across the metals complex. Copper rose to 5.86 USD/Lbs on January 9, 2026, up 2.17% from the previous day, and is up 37.59% compared to the same time last year.

item.title: Copper supplies set to peak just as tech needs more
item.description: A new S&P Global study warns that global copper production is likely to peak this decade even as demand from electrification, EVs, and AI infrastructure accelerates. The article highlights constraints on mine output, long lead times for new projects, and the concentration of 40–50% of global smelting and refining capacity in China, raising concerns about future supply security and processing bottlenecks.[3]

item.title: AI to boost copper demand 50% by 2040 — S&P
item.description: Reporting on a new S&P Global study, this piece notes that global copper demand is forecast to rise 50% to about 42 million tonnes a year by 2040, while mine production is expected to peak at roughly 33 million tonnes in 2030. Even with recycled copper output more than doubling to 10 million tonnes, S&P projects an annual supply gap of around 10 million tonnes by 2040 without substantial new mine and processing capacity.[4]

item.title: Rio Tinto and Glencore announce merger plans to create world's largest copper miner
item.description: Rio Tinto and Glencore have unveiled plans to merge their businesses, in a move that would create the world’s largest copper miner by production capacity. The deal is framed around capturing growing demand and improving supply security in the copper market, with the combined entity expected to control a significantly larger share of global mine output and project pipelines.[5]

item.title: Copper supply shortfall expected to widen
item.description: A summary of the S&P Global *Copper in the Age of AI* study explains that copper demand is expected to increase by 50% to 42 million metric tons by 2040, driven by AI-related electricity use, defense spending, energy transition technologies, and core economic growth.[5] Even with a projected doubling of recycled copper scrap from 4 to 10 million metric tons, the article stresses that new and expanded mines will be needed due to technical, environmental, and regulatory hurdles facing primary production.[5]

item.title: Global Demand for Copper Surges 50% by 2040
item.description: This piece discusses how electrification, AI infrastructure, and renewable energy are set to push global copper demand up by about 50% by 2040, based largely on findings from S&P Global’s *Copper in the Age of AI* study.[6][3] It emphasizes that without major investment in mining, processing, and recycling technologies, copper could shift from being an enabler of the energy transition and digitalization to a constraint on sustainable growth.[6][3]

item.title: Nickel Plunges from Over 2-Year High as Markets Reassess Indonesian Output Cuts
item.description: Nickel futures fell to about $17,100 per tonne after briefly touching a more than two-year high of $18,875 on January 6, as traders reassessed the scale and credibility of Indonesia’s proposed 34% cut to its 2026 nickel mining quota.[2] Despite talk of curbs, Russia’s Nornickel still projects a 275,000-tonne surplus next year and LME stockpiles climbed to 255,000 tonnes in 2025, underscoring ongoing oversupply concerns.[2]

item.title: Pressure for Indonesian Quota U-Turn Is a Risk for Nickel Price Rally
item.description: Indonesia, which accounts for about 70% of global nickel production (around 3.8 million tonnes last year), has lifted prices close to 19‑month highs by announcing cuts to mining quotas aimed at boosting revenues.[5] Analysts warn the rally may be short‑lived because many new Indonesian projects are due onstream in 2026 and industry pressure could force the government to ease quotas later in the year, allowing miners to reapply for higher production permits.[5]

item.title: Hydro joins Alumobility to accelerate aluminium adoption in the automotive industry
item.description: Hydro announced it has joined **Alumobility**, a global ecosystem aimed at advancing aluminium use in lighter, more energy‑efficient and circular vehicles.[2] By contributing its low‑carbon production expertise and full value‑chain capabilities, Hydro seeks to drive innovation in lightweight, sustainable aluminium solutions for automakers worldwide.[2]

item.title: Copper Pushes Higher With Metals Set for Fourth Weekly Advance
item.description: Copper, aluminum and other industrial metals climbed again, extending a strong multi-week rally driven by tightening supplies, increased shipments to the US, and rising investor enthusiasm for commodities.[5] Nickel, tin and copper each gained more than 2% in London, with copper moving back toward its record above $13,300 a tonne set earlier in the week, as the LMEX base metals index headed for a fourth straight weekly advance.[5]

item.title: Copper rises with bets on future demand growth
item.description: Copper prices advanced on Friday and were set for a fourth consecutive week of gains, supported by renewed bets on future demand growth.[7] The move higher came alongside strength in aluminium and other base metals, as investors positioned for stronger medium-term consumption linked to industrial and energy-transition demand.[7]

item.title: Rio Tinto may buy Glencore to form mining leader with copper prices near record
item.description: Glencore and Rio Tinto announced merger talks on January 9, 2026, which could create the world's biggest mining company amid soaring metal prices. The deal follows Anglo American's acquisition of Teck Resources and comes as analysts view it as a critical moment for industry consolidation.

item.title: Nickel prices hit 15-month high on robust sentiment
item.description: Nickel prices on major exchanges climbed to a 15‑month high on 6 January, supported by strong investor sentiment linked to macroeconomic developments and possible changes to Indonesia’s mining plans.[4] LME nickel reached about $18,045/ton, up 7% day‑on‑day and roughly 20% above mid‑December levels, with SHFE nickel also hitting its daily limit.[4]

item.title: Nickel prices hit 15-month high on robust sentiment
item.description: Nickel prices climbed to a 15‑month high on strong market sentiment, supported by broader gains in base metals and expectations that Indonesian policy changes may tighten ore supply and raise production costs.[6] Market participants report that Indonesia could cut its nickel ore work plan and budget (RKAB) to 250 million tonnes in 2026 from about 379 million tonnes in 2025, even as domestic ore consumption is projected to rise, implying a potential squeeze on available ore for processing capacity.[6]

item.title: Nickel Prices Jump After Top Producer Indonesia Signals 2026 Output Cut
item.description: Indonesia announced plans to cut nickel production in 2026 to better balance global supply and demand, triggering a jump in nickel prices on the London Metal Exchange.[2] The government intends to adjust miners’ production quotas after years of rapidly rising output that lifted Indonesia’s share of global nickel production from about 31.5% in 2020 to over 60% in 2024, aiming to reduce surplus and support prices while addressing environmental concerns.[2]

item.title: Alcoa, Ball and Unilever pioneer carbon-free aluminum packaging with ELYSIS technology
item.description: Alcoa, in partnership with Ball Corporation and Unilever, announced the first commercial use of **ELYSIS carbon-free aluminum smelting technology** in consumer aerosol packaging.[1] The can uses 50% ELYSIS primary aluminum and 50% post‑consumer recycled content, eliminating direct greenhouse gas emissions from smelting and significantly lowering the packaging’s carbon footprint.[1]

item.title: Lloyds Engineering Works Signs Technology Licensing Agreement with US-Based The Material Works
item.description: Lloyds Engineering Works has entered a strategic technology licensing partnership with U.S.-based The Material Works to deploy **EPS Generation 4** steel surface-cleaning technology.[4] The process replaces traditional acid-based pickling with an eco‑friendly system that uses recyclable materials, achieves zero effluent discharge, and eliminates hazardous acid chemicals, improving both sustainability and production efficiency in steel processing.[4]

item.title: Nickel price extends drop amid lack of detail on Indonesia output cuts
item.description: Nickel retreated from a recent 19‑month high after Indonesia failed to provide details on its pledged production cuts, which had previously driven a sharp price rally.[5] Three‑month LME nickel futures fell as much as 5.9%, settling 4.1% lower at about $17,155/ton, with analysts warning that price sustainability depends on meaningful and consistent quota reductions.[5]

item.title: Global nickel market recalibrates after explosive trading week
item.description: Following a volatile week marked by a spike above $18,000/ton, three‑month LME nickel hovered near $17,900/ton as the market reassessed the impact of Indonesia’s planned output cuts and recent speculative flows.[7] Traders reported a shift from aggressive buying to more cautious positioning, with attention focused on how firmly Jakarta will enforce reduced nickel mining quotas.[7]

item.title: Indonesia releases January (Period I) benchmark prices for nickel ore
item.description: Indonesia’s nickel miners association set the January Period I benchmark nickel ore reference price at about $14,630/wmt, a 0.21% increase from late‑December levels.[2] FOB prices for higher‑grade ore rose marginally across Ni 1.6–2.0% grades, reflecting firmer demand and the broader upswing in nickel markets.[2]

item.title: Nickel price extends drop amid lack of detail on Indonesia output cuts
item.description: Nickel prices fell sharply from a 19‑month high after Indonesia, the world’s largest nickel producer, failed to provide specifics on planned mining quota cuts that had previously driven a strong price rally.[5] The article notes that three‑month LME nickel futures, which had surged to about $18,800/t on expectations of reduced Indonesian supply, pulled back as analysts warned that any impact on global production capacity may be limited unless meaningful quota reductions are implemented and maintained.[5]

item.title: CRITICAL MINERALS CURRENTS (January 10, 2026)
item.description: A critical minerals market update notes that nickel prices have recently hit highs near $18,500/t, supported by investor sentiment and emerging supply constraints.[1] The report situates nickel within broader efforts by the United States and its allies to boost domestic production and reduce reliance on China for critical mineral refining and processing capacity.[1]

item.title: Steel – Price, Chart, Historical Data and Market News
item.description: Steel rebar futures are trading above 3,120 CNY/ton and near multi‑month highs, supported by expectations that China will roll out new policy measures to bolster economic growth and steel demand.[1] The People’s Bank of China plans to lower the reserve requirement ratio and cut key policy rates in 2026, while current data show steel at 3,128 CNY/ton on January 9, up 0.55% on the day and 1.66% over the past month, though still slightly below year‑ago levels.[1]

item.title: Acciaierie d'Italia to start preferential negotiations with Azerbaijani consortium on acquisition of former Ilva plants
item.description: Extraordinary commissioners of Acciaierie d’Italia and ILVA in extraordinary administration have requested authorization from Italy’s Ministry of Enterprises and Made in Italy to begin preferential negotiations with an Azerbaijani consortium (Baku Steel Company CJSC and Azerbaijan Investment Company OJSC) for the sale of the former Ilva steel plants.[8] Ten proposals had been received by the January 10 deadline, and the chosen consortium was selected based on criteria including financial stability, industrial sustainability, and expected benefits for employment and local communities.[8]
